messages.text: What do we need to do to start supporting the arm64 macs on BB? <https://twitter.com/josef_heinen/status/1341758413169172481>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/josef_heinen|@josef_heinen>: Pleased to see that GR runs natively under macOS 11 Big Sur on arm64 (Apple M1) using #SwiftLang. Now the only thing missing is a native #JuliaLang distribution. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep7h0NDXUAM-8eQ.jpg>
attachments.text: Pleased to see that GR runs natively under macOS 11 Big Sur on arm64 (Apple M1) using #SwiftLang. Now the only thing missing is a native #JuliaLang distribution. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ep7h0NDXUAM-8eQ.jpg>

elements.text: What do we need to do to start supporting the arm64 macs on BB?

messages.text: Basically, move the platform from experimental to supported?

elements.text: Basically, move the platform from experimental to supported?

messages.text: JLL packages with aarch64 darwin binaries will work only on julia v1.6.  I think we'll need to keep them as experimental for a while

elements.text: JLL packages with aarch64 darwin binaries will work only on julia v1.6.  I think we'll need to keep them as experimental for a while

messages.text: to be clear, packages can already be built for the new platforms on a case-by-case basis, but they _must_ require Julia v1.6 and they _must_ bump the version number if they had a previous build.  but please, no rush

elements.text: to be clear, packages can already be built for the new platforms on a case-by-case basis, but they

Julia v1.6 doesn’t build cleanly on aarch64 darwin yet.  I believe the next hurdle is to get a PCRE patch that Keno submitted to an upstream dependency of PCRE (to avoid a crash) but we’re not certain if PCRE has released a version with that update dependency yet

If you need to change the build number it’s not so hard; just check out the JLL source code, `s/11.0.0+4/11.0.0+5` in all the files (should be `Project.toml`, `README.md` and `Artifacts.toml`), commit that, then go to releases and change the release name (which will create a new tag on the commit you just pushed up)

messages.text: <@UCTJ1TGBV> Well, at least assuming you want to in the end publish a JLL to Yggdrasil. The thing is, this uses a recent BB dev snapshot, which in turn requires features from Julia 1.6. So you need to go get yourself a nightly build of Julia (download one or compile from git sources). Then you can run `julia-nightly --project=PATH/TO/Yggdrasil/.ci` and the first time around, run `Pkg.instantiate()` and then you should be able to use the environment (which will ensure you are testing in setup that is close to what you will see on Yggdrasil).

messages.text: Exponential versioning
v3e38

so, we now need to update FLINT_jll from 2.6 to 2.7. Unfortunately that means a new SONAME, and so we'll also have to update the JLLs for arb, antic, normaliz, singular, (and then possibly also libsingular_julia), polymake, (and then possibly also libpolymake_julia). Anyway, I've now come up with this idea, and wanted to air it here in the hopes that <@UDB26738Q> <@U66GD0880> <@U01CH05FTMM> <@U85R3JJ8L> etc. will tell me whether I am crazy or not :wink:. The idea is to imitate the approach taken by LLVM_full_jll and the derived JLLs:  I would make a single big Oscar_jll which builds and installs all of the above. Then the new FLINT_jll, Arb_jll, etc. build recipes would download a specific version of Oscar_jll, and copy from it the parts they need.   This has multiple advantages:
1. instead of having to make ~N (for N = number of involved JLLs) staggered PRs (in practice over several days or even weeks) a total of two PRs suffice to update everything
2. *testing* of updates is _much_ easier: I submit a draft update to Oscar_jll; then download the archive it produces and then can use it as override for FLINT_jll, arb_jll etc. simultaneously, and can test with that
3. if I notice an issue in the testing step, I just revise my single Oscar_jll PR, until all is good. (Right now, it can happen that after say 5 of the N PRs are merged, we notice a problem that means we have to start over at step 1 of the chain)
4. it ensures that all the different libraries really, *really* have been built against the correct versions of each other; this eliminates a whole class of (human) errors

etc. will tell me whether I am crazy or not

if I notice an issue in the testing step, I just revise my single Oscar_jll PR, until all is good. (Right now, it can happen that after say 5 of the N PRs are merged, we notice a problem that means we have to start over at step 1 of the chain)
it ensures that all the different libraries really,
have been built against the correct versions of each other; this eliminates a whole class of (human) errors
